content.description: This route ascends the blunt arete in the middle of the crag, on the left side of a gully that splits the crag into 2 sections.  Featured rock down low gives way to the slabby arete with crux moves up high.

An anchor exists between

R&C's...

and

Sweet Pea...

. You can swing and climb over to it from the anchor on

Sweet Pea...

to set a toprope, but it shows evidence of being cleaned out and was likely led on gear or could be.
content.location:
It is in between

R&C's...

and

Sweet Pea...

.

climbs.name: Sweet Pea Got Her Groove On

content.description: This short bolted route is on the far right side of Reese's Pieces.  It starts by climbing a small pillar with good edges, then it moves right onto the slabbier face to finish.

This route climbs the obvious left-leaning dihedral on the right side the West face of Reese's Pieces.  It starts with steep face moves protected by bolts down low, then it gains the ledge just below the dihedral.  One final bolt protects entry moves into the dihedral. Stems and opposition moves are needed on both sides of the dihedral as you work your way through the crux early.  Cruise up and reach for the big jug ledge on the right side, then finish to the 2-bolt anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts, a 1" cam up high, and 1 runner for the bolt at the base of the dihedral.

content.description:
Climb cracks that parallel

Le Divorce

, the route to the left with a single bolt, finishing at the same anchor. Climb the thin cracks left of the bush-filled wide cracks.
content.location:
It is downhill from

Sweet Pea...

and left of a bushy crack system.

content.description:
This is the well-bolted face climb just right of the "

Yes-O-Yes

" blunt arete.  Work up coarse, frictiony granite with rounded ribs in a nice mixture of face & slab moves.  The crux is about halfway up over the right side of a bulge.  Finish by moving far left to the shared anchors with "

Yes-O-Yes

."

This climb ascends the left side of the face just around the corner from the "

Softail Meets Guardrail

" dihedral.  Look for the single bolt down low to identify the route.  Start with face moves down low, then follow the leftmost crack near the arete for a great finish.  Improbable feet underneath the arete provide an exciting position.
content.protection: 1 bolt down low, small-to-medium stoppers, and cams to 2".  The crux is up high and protectable by a bomber stopper in a slot.

content.description:
Harley Learning Curve shares the same start as "

Softail Meets Guardrail

", but after gaining the ledge, the route splits left onto the face, eventually meeting up at the same 2-bolt anchor.  One thin move in the middle of the face defines the crux.

climbs.name: Goin' Down to Aspen With My Platinum Card in My Chanel Clutch

content.description:
This is probably the best route at Reese's Pieces, plus what a route name!

Climb a cruxy, bolt protected face section to a section of double crack to a ledge. Move right to another ledge and to the top.
content.location: It is the leftmost route at Reese's.

content.description:
This route is in the middle of Reese's Pieces and can be identified by an overhanging bulge down low leading to steep face climbing and ultimately a pointed roof.

A bouldery start gets you off the ground and to the first bolt, which is noticeably far left from the rest of the bolt line.  It's probably best to unclip the first bolt after you clip the 2nd to reduce rope drag.  Steep but juggy climbing takes you into to the roof, which takes a bomber cam placement and requires reaching high for the jug or slithering around to the right to surpass.
content.protection: 6 bolts, a #0.75 Camalot needed to protect the roof crux, and a 2 bolt anchor up top.
